We provide a purely categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are similar to those of the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators on them. The definition is intended to be a foundation for quantum theory, and it is used to provide a new proof of the Kochen–Specker theorem.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest to the scientific community because of their unique structure and lifestyle. However, the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and the group has been considered a “living fossil.” Here, we report the results of a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in gene content and that the group is a sister taxon to the cnidarians. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main strategies used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton (Hv1) channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This will increase the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We quantify the magnitude of this instability and its consequences for the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. Our results highlight the need for urgent investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree to which species partition food resources is dependent on the taxonomic resolution of diet analysis. At coarse trophic levels of categorization, such as “grazer” and “browser,” species were similar in diet composition, and dietary overlap was high between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. However, at finer taxonomic levels of categorization, species were dissimilar in diet composition, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorization may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Thus, the taxonomic resolution of diet analysis may be critical to understanding the role of large herbivores in biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but they anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the plastic debris in the open ocean is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but in much smaller amounts than expected. This is due to the selective removal of the smaller plastic fragments by the food web and the ocean interior.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 presolar grains that formed in the interstellar medium. We found that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring, such as milk, is a strong driver of reproductive output. We also show that the ability to provide resources to offspring, such as milk, is a strong driver of reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is well tolerated in humans, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA and other synucleinopathies. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other neurodegenerative diseases, in which α-syn is involved. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues. It is the most numerous cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues, control inflammation, and control the contractility of the blood vessels. The endothelium is able to control these functions using a network of cells that are specialized to detect specific stimuli. This paper describes the nature of the communication network that the endothelium uses to control these functions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the data needs of the public health community have been enormous. We have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that this infrastructure will be useful to the public health community and to researchers and policymakers who are working to understand and respond to the pandemic.

Potassium channels are a large family of proteins that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. They are also involved in a number of diseases, such as cardiac arrhythmias and epilepsy. In this work, we have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is influenced by the host and the environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identified a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products, and we detected many of these natural products in the culture supernatants of anaerobic fungi. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This study provides a foundation for future research on the biosynthesis of natural products by anaerobic fungi and their potential as a source of novel compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that the low probability of becoming dominant in high-anxious animals can be reversed by pharmacological interventions that enhance mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design and manufacturing approaches are limited in terms of the complexity of the target behaviors and the programmability of the devices. Here, we propose a synthesis and manufacturing strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The structures are digitally synthesized and then manufactured into devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors, which can be applied to a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacturing of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key example of a developmental program that is regulated by the circadian clock. In this study we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key element in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway that is involved in the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal period and is down-regulated in the adult period. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 mediates the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This is important for understanding the role of the circadian clock in the development of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is required for the ferroptosis resistance of cancer cells with mutation of the PTEN tumor suppressor, and that this resistance is mediated by the mTORC1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that the SREBP1-mediated induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) is required for this resistance. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy in patients with PTEN-mutant or PI3K-mutated cancer. Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM1 and ORAI1. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in patients with hypertension and low risk of heart failure. This study also suggests that LCCBs should be used with caution in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the policy’s effects on bird populations were complex and varied by forest type. The policy halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the policy’s effects on early-seral–associated birds were mixed, with declines in two ecoregions, but stable early-seral area. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for continued monitoring of bird populations and forest conditions to assess the effectiveness of the NWFP. (Read more)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. In this work, we present a rational design strategy for the development of new acylide antibiotics. The strategy is based on the use of computational tools to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of the designed compounds to the ribosome. We show that the predicted best candidate is more active than telithromycin, which is the only approved acylide antibiotic, and is more soluble and more permeable to the cell membrane. The strategy was applied to the design of a new class of acylide antibiotics, which are currently being tested in clinical trials. The results of this work are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to combat antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the network with a large number of training examples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The Lake Malawi region is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth, and the lake has been a critical habitat for the evolution of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the lake has been highly dynamic over the past 1.3 My, with 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m. The record shows that the lake was much lower in the past, and that the climate was drier than today. The lake has been a critical habitat for the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock, and the rapid speciation that occurred in response to the changing hydroclimate is a unique example of the evolutionary response to environmental change.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with a number of negative health consequences, including reduced sleep duration and quality, reduced daytime alertness, and an increased risk of accidents. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can also suppress melatonin, phase-delay the circadian clock, and reduce the amount of sleep that is obtained the next morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Younger Dryas (YDB) boundary is one of the most important events in the Earth’s history, but the cause of the YDB is still debated. One of the most compelling hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB. In this paper, we show that the osmium isotopic composition of the bolide ejecta is consistent with the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system has been extensively studied, but the function of CTLA-4 in the adult organism is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a variety of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be ameliorated by the presence of Tregs. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target in autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding and the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the evolution of the population than for the evolution of the individual.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE E4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This study reveals a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 1,200 km in height. It is the densest part of the planet, and it is the only part of the planet that is not molten. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to form and impossible to observe. In this paper, we propose a mechanism for the formation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. We therefore sought to understand how language is processed in the brain. We found that deep learning models that predict which word will come next in a sequence of spoken words do so by predicting the next word in the sentence. This finding provides a computational mechanism for how the human brain processes language. It also suggests that the language system in the brain is tuned to the task of predicting the next word in a sequence. This finding has implications for understanding the neural mechanisms of language and may help to inform the design of better artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many problems in scientific computing are well-conditioned, meaning that there exist algorithms that can compute stable solutions to the problem. We introduce a new class of algorithms, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of scientific controversy. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major cause of the crisis. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its widespread use, its design flaws have been overlooked. Here, we discuss the flaws and their consequences, and we offer a more accurate account of the experiment. We hope that this case study will serve as a cautionary tale for researchers and students of psychology.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied in great detail, but the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon, which is similar to leprosy but is not associated with transmission, is still unknown. We have sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is the causative agent of this disease, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We find that the two organisms are remarkably conserved and that they are still able to cause disease in humans. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the development of new therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum and statistical mechanics. They are the main ingredients of the quantum theory of information, which is the foundation of the new technology of quantum computing. The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is therefore of fundamental importance. We show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, which is exact in some paradigmatic cases, is sufficient to understand the dynamics in general. This is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, which will allow for a more systematic study of the entanglement of interacting systems, a field of great current interest.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, has a high safety margin, and is highly protective.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by recurrent epidemics and high mortality. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and the evolution of vector-borne diseases.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is more complex than the evolution of brain size alone. This study shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from one lineage to another. This study also shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from one lineage to another.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that TRAP1 may be a potential therapeutic target in cancer. (Cancer Res; 73(1): 10–20. ©2012 AACR.)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell shape changes. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin is able to sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, and we propose a mechanochemical model to explain this observation. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin is able to sever actin filaments in cells. They also suggest that the mechanical state of the filament network may be an important determinant of the activity of ADF/cofilin. This work may help us understand how ADF/cofilin is able to control the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in foods and beverages. This study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater desire for food and food-related behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only place where the Bantu and Austronesian languages are spoken, and it is the only place where the two continents of Africa and Asia are represented in the genetic heritage of the population. We show that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher influx of men from Southeast Asia. The genetic structure of the population is also influenced by the geography of the island, suggesting that the settlement happened in a nonuniform way. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the human history of the region.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment that shows that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social networks that are more positive and supportive. It also has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have a profound impact on the translation of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can increase the rate of translation of the mRNA. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can increase the rate of translation of the mRNA. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this sense of worthwhile living is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and greater longevity. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and physical and mental health. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is one of the most striking patterns in the history of life. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of the virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of the host is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the disease. This study demonstrates that the host response to rhinovirus infection is more efficient at the core body temperature of the host than at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity. This difference in host response may contribute to the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This sensing mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to detect the presence of surfaces on short timescales, which is critical for its ability to cause disease. The results also suggest that the type IV pili are mechanosensitive, and that the mechanical activity of the pili can be used as a signal for the regulation of gene expression. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of bacterial virulence. It also has implications for the design of antibacterial strategies that target bacterial sensing systems.

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global concern. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global situation, which is based on a metaanalysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living white-tailed deer, and the detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the lymph nodes of deer, during the winter months, when deer are expected to be in isolation. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the challenges of climate change and the need to incorporate it into the consideration of whether to build a dam. The paper also examines the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, the paper proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to the sustained activation of microglia, a type of immune cell, in response to the presence of Aβ plaques. However, in the earliest stages of the disease, when there are no Aβ plaques, the immune response is still present. We show that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is the cause of this immune response, and that it is unique to neurons. This study provides a better understanding of the disease process and may lead to the development of new treatments.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the history of animal domestication and for the development of the chicken as a food animal. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of proteins is a complex process that is not yet understood. One of the most important questions is how the protein unfolds. This study shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a heterogeneous state, which is followed by a slower formation of a distinct intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway and is the site of three destabilizing mutations. The intermediate is also the site of three stabilizing mutations that slow the folding of the wild-type protein. These results suggest that the intermediate is a key step in the folding of the protein.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they are capped at their 5′ ends with a nucleoside triphosphate, which is removed by a decapping enzyme. In this study, we show that the enzyme that removes the cap from RNA is also responsible for removing the cap from DNA, a finding that has implications for the degradation of DNA in response to stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune dysfunction that occurs in sepsis is associated with the expansion of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Treg), which are known to be involved in the pathogenesis of sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential adjuvant in cancer therapy. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s response to small perturbations is independent of its initial state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanical properties of diamond and to control its deformation. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the relationship between the bandgap and the elastic properties of diamond. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the mode of action of a structurally unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a large family of nodule-specific cysteine-rich peptides, against plant fungal pathogens. We show that the peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and in planta, and that it breaches the fungal cell wall and penetrates the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. (Less)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection and the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and demonstrate that the female reproductive tract is a critical site of molecular continuity between males and females. Our research provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of the male–female reproductive axis and the evolution of sex differences. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. We show that force application to the platelet surface switches the conformation of VWF, increasing the rate of binding to GPIbα. This is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of the blood that is caused by mutations in VWF. The results are important for understanding the role of force in the regulation of protein−protein interactions. They also provide a mechanism for the effects of mutations in VWF. The results are relevant to understanding the role of force in other protein−protein interactions.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a resource for the community, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 million viral sequences, all of which are available for download. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results are expected to have a major impact on the field of human microbiome research.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth was likely very high, but the extent to which it cooled over geological time has been the subject of debate. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the early Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the early Earth’s surface decreased over time, a finding consistent with previous interpretations based on isotopic evidence.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are composed of a protein skeleton and a pore-forming domain. The pore domain is the main target of drugs and also the main site of action of many toxins. Ion channels are also the main targets of many diseases. The present study provides a detailed description of the structure and function of the pore domain of the K+ channel BK.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 1 million deaths occurring each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the process of invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is important to understand the mechanical properties of diamond and to control its deformation. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can vanish. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the mechanism of metallization in other materials. (Show more)

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection remains unclear. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the role of ambient humidity in the severity of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in a wide range of processes, including cell fate determination, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin, which are genetically redundant.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat, and this effect can be blocked by dopamine antagonists. Here we show that this stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), and that this circuit is necessary for the development of overeating. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is not mediated by the LH neurons themselves, but rather by a circuit that includes the LH and the locus coeruleus. Thus, we have identified a circuit that may contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of all plants. However, the amount of N2 fixed by the atmosphere is far greater than that taken up by plants, and the process is limited by the availability of N2-fixing bacteria. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology has the potential to revolutionize agriculture and is expected to have a significant impact on the global nitrogen cycle. (Less)

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed forest monitoring systems are used to detect and track deforestation, but they are often too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be used to monitor other natural resources, such as fisheries and water resources.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The lack of a vaccine has been a major obstacle to containing the pandemic. Here we report the design and development of a subunit vaccine candidate that can be produced at a large scale, which is a key requirement for global access. The vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, which is the target of the currently approved vaccines. The variant is engineered to be manufacturable at high yield, to bind to the ACE2 receptor with high affinity, and to elicit antibodies with enhanced neutralizing activity against variants of concern. The vaccine candidate is presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces the weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This work provides a potential vaccine candidate that can be manufactured at a large scale, which is a key requirement for global access. The vaccine candidate can be used as a component of a combination vaccine, or as a standalone vaccine.

The role of the ALK/ALKALS family of receptors in the development of the nervous system is still unclear. Here we show that the ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/ALKALS family of receptors in vivo. This is the first evidence that the ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/ALKALS family of receptors in vivo. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/ALKALS family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development.

The emergence of plague, the deadliest pathogen in human history, is a mystery that has been the subject of intense research for centuries. The study of ancient genomes has provided a unique window into the past, allowing us to explore the origins of this pathogen. Here, we present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its relationship to its host. This work also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its relationship to its host. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitim

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the carbon cycle of the land–atmosphere system. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can be used to mitigate this release. We show that the management of grasslands and the integration of livestock can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. This study highlights the importance of grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to viral threats originating in animals. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive tool for the public to access and use this information. We hope that this tool will be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and rapid control of viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards that plants offer to pollinators is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the red color of the nectar of N. mauritianus.

We have developed a method to sequence the genomes of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 500 and 700 AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that of women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. We also find that women with artificial skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that is very different from that of other individuals in the sample. This indicates that they may have had a different appearance, and that the genetic ancestry of these individuals is not consistent with that of modern Europeans. Finally, we find that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This indicates that the genetic landscape of Europe was already changing at this time. Together, these results provide insights into the complex demographic processes that may have contributed to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results also establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings are important for understanding the evolution of bat coronaviruses and for developing strategies to prevent their cross-species transmission and the ensuing pandemics. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of mNGS to detect a broad range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings, and the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the stability of the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique insight into the molecular basis of lagging strand DNA synthesis in humans. They also suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme may be a key factor in the development of cancer. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but the process is inefficient. Here, we report the results of an effort to improve the efficiency of RNA replication by selecting variants of a ribozyme that catalyze the process more efficiently. The improved polymerase ribozyme is able to replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that our method will be used to study the physical changes in cities around the world.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical patients is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a toxic metal that can be detrimental to the health of the cell. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of isocyanide metabolites in fungal physiology and the potential for these compounds to be exploited for therapeutic purposes. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) phase that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of this phase in a sedimentary rock in a crater lake setting is a unique discovery. The presence of this phase in a sedimentary rock in a crater lake setting is a unique discovery.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is region-specific.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear what role these cells play in the pathogenesis of the disease. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, and that they are able to support the development of Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease, and that targeting this subset of cells may be a useful strategy for the treatment of the disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. We have developed a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This approach will be useful for ALS research and drug development. It will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases, as well as other diseases that are caused by toxicity of other cell types.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed by the tick Ixodes scapularis and is critical for the survival of the pathogen. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the complex interactions between pathogens and their arthropod vectors. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing, and that this increase is playing an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the color of the animal can be modified by pigments, such as carotenoids and phycobilins. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green colors, which are often associated with high concentrations of biliverdin. We show that the presence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide evidence of the recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green color in anurans. These findings are important for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates and the function of serpins.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), a m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression decreases NANOG mRNA methylation, increases NANOG levels, and increases the percentage of BCSCs, phenocopying the effect of hypoxia. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our findings provide insight into the role of ALKBH5 in breast cancer and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world, and the first pocket Bible was a major technological advance. The source of the parchment, however, has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. In this study, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα is critical for the control of intestinal inflammation, which is associated with the up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Our findings suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the receptor–binding domain of the spike, and the fusion domain of the spike. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike has resulted in a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a significant improvement over the previous best result, which only holds for games with finitely many players. Our result is also a significant improvement over the previous best result for games with finitely many players, which only holds for games with finitely many actions per player. Our result is also a significant improvement over the previous best result for games with finitely many actions per player, which only holds for games with finitely many players.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as physics, biology, and geology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.
