Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is less well understood. We show that changes in human demography can suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate policy and management of fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with the body of an animal is a common feature of symbiosis. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the luminescence of the symbiont is required. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy for maintaining the stability of animal-associated microbial communities. This strategy may be particularly important for symbioses that are dependent on the activity of the associated microbes, such as those that produce light or chemical defenses. (Read more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify the latent patterns that describe the data. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which we integrate with word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method provides a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that this method will be used to identify latent patterns in many domains.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a mass mortality event. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the virus. This is the first report of a disease agent causing mass mortality in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common hematological malignancies, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that the IL1RAP-targeting antibody can be used to treat AML in mice. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a strategy for the treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only place where the Bantu and Austronesian languages meet, and it is the only place where the genetic diversity of both Africa and Asia is present. We show that the settlement history of Madagascar is complex and that the island was settled by a mixture of people from different parts of Africa and Asia.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with two different promoters and that the translation of the protein interferes with the base-pairing function. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions compete, and that the protein can have multiple functions. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop expert surveys are a valuable source of information on crop status, but are often underutilized. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. We also show that the CPC survey is not only useful for monitoring crop status, but can also be used to estimate the yield of a given crop across the country. Finally, we show that the CPC survey is not only useful for monitoring crop status, but can also be used to estimate the yield of a given crop across the country.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain’s language network. However, the neural substrates of language processing are still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the brain’s ability to integrate information over time. We show that the activity of a single neuron can be used to encode information about the sequence of words in a sentence. This information is then used to predict the next word in the sentence. Our model is based on the idea that information is stored in the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons, rather than in the membrane potential. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also has implications for our understanding of memory and attention.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to warming across a range of biomes. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool for understanding the history of photosynthesis and the evolution of the eukaryotic cell. However, the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is also a reflection of the evolutionary history of the host cell, and the evolution of the host cell is shaped by the environment. Here, we show that the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is shaped by the evolutionary history of the host cell, and that the evolutionary history of the host cell is shaped by the environment.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This is a significant contribution to the drought risk in the region, which is highly sensitive to future emissions. Our results highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the intensification of droughts in the future.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been one of the most important developments in science in the 21st century. The first naturally occurring quasicrystal was discovered in the Khatyrka meteorite in 2005. Here, we report the discovery of a second naturally occurring quasicrystal in red trinitite, a sample of sand and glass from the Trinity test of the first nuclear bomb. The discovery of this second naturally occurring quasicrystal provides a unique link between the discovery of the first naturally occurring quasicrystal and the development of the nuclear bomb.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the characteristic feature of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. Here we show that the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is a subunit-based reaction, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of the enzyme in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of a dual ASK1 inhibitor for the treatment of neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occur when conditions are warm are more likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. Finally, we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the core autistic symptoms and may help in the development of new treatments for autism. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel complex result in a variety of human diseases. Here, we identify a range of mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein and in the Ca2+ sensing protein that can alter the function of the channel, and we use these mutations to understand the phenotypic spectrum of the diseases associated with them. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the diseases associated with the mutations, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a transcellular manner, and that this spreading is dependent on the internalization of aggregates. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the endocytic machinery, and that this is important for the progression of the disease. These results provide a model for the study of the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic target to treat viral infections in humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is a key metabolic enzyme that converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We have identified a cancer cell-line screen that identifies SHMT as a targetable metabolic pathway in cancer. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency in one of the most common cancers, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, that is targetable with our SHMT inhibitor. Our work provides a metabolic rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy, and a metabolic target for the development of new cancer therapies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, they are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely to be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, and may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic and the origin of this group is poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. Our study shows that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is considered to be the sister group of eudicots. This study also shows that the origin of the flowering plants was earlier than previously thought and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early flowering plant lineages.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as well as to the general public. However, the study of virus evolution is complicated by the fact that viruses are typically not cultured in the laboratory, and thus, the study of their evolution is based on the analysis of genetic sequences. Here we present the analysis of ancient viral sequences, which are of great interest for the study of virus evolution and phylogenetics.

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a simple, quantitative estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is important because sea level is a key indicator of climate change, and because the rate of rise is a key parameter in many coastal management and planning decisions.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key element in understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain, and the structure of the enzyme–product complex is even more difficult to obtain. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–product complex, and how this structure can be used to understand the mechanism of the enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that the antiviral remdesivir, which is in clinical use for the treatment of Ebola, effectively inhibited MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) replication in vitro, and showed efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronavirus infections.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with the body of an animal is a common feature of symbiosis. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of a symbiotic community, and that this glycan is provided and metabolized only at night. This glycan is likely to be a critical nutrient for the symbiotic community, and the timing of its provision is likely to be critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis. We propose that this strategy is likely to be common in animal-microbe interactions, and that it may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

This study shows that it is possible to reduce the use of suspension in schools. The study also shows that it is possible to change the way teachers think about discipline. This is a major contribution to the field of education, and it has implications for the way we think about the role of teachers in society.

The present study provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results are expected to provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis in vivo. This work also provides mechanistic insights into the design of DNA alkylation-resistant drugs.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations compromised infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Our findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental problems. One promising approach to reducing the environmental impact of food consumption is to increase the proportion of plant-based meals in the diets of people in high-income countries. However, this is a difficult goal to achieve because people’s preferences for meat are strong and well-established. We show that it is possible to increase the proportion of plant-based meals offered in cafeterias by 50% without a detectable rebound effect. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in many settings. Our results suggest that it may be possible to make a significant contribution to environmental sustainability by changing the food environment in which people make decisions. This approach could be used to complement other efforts to reduce the environmental impact of food consumption. (Less)

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic and complex system that is involved in a wide range of cellular functions, including cell–cell communication, immune surveillance, and cancer progression. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the effects of oncogenes on the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion. We find that the oncogenes have a strong impact on the surfaceome, and that the oncogenes are able to induce similar changes to the surfaceome in a coordinated fashion. We also find that the oncogenes have a strong impact on the glycoproteome, and that the glycoproteome is also impacted by the MEK inhibitor, which blocks the MAPK pathway. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the cell surface proteome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of vaccines and therapeutics. The structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein provides insight into the molecular basis of the disease and the development of effective countermeasures.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in the rat brain and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We also show that CRF acts on the CRF receptor CRFR1 in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and that this contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. In conclusion, hypobaric hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies.

We live in an age of big data, where the size of the data is large compared to the number of parameters in the statistical model. This makes it difficult to assess the significance of the associations that we find. We describe a general approach to this problem, which we call selective inference. We illustrate the approach in the context of forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will stimulate further research in this exciting area.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of many vascular diseases. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular diseases. It also provides a potential approach for the regeneration of damaged organs, such as the liver. This study will also help us understand the mechanism of EC development induced by ETV2.

The identification of “orphan” RTKs with oncogenic potential has led to the discovery of their physiological ligands. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leukocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are essential for the development of iridophores, a unique type of photoreceptor that is found in the zebrafish retina and in the skin of adult fish. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insight into the function of augmentor ligands and their role in the development of a unique type of photoreceptor. It also provides a model for the study of the function of augmentor ligands in other organisms. (Show more)

The role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established. However, its function in β-cell is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to change their genome sequence, which is a major obstacle for the development of effective vaccines and drugs. One of the main reasons for this is the existence of a packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and is sequence specific. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a molecular understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. They also suggest that the existence of a selective packaging mechanism might be more general than previously thought. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disruption of the local hemodynamic environment. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerosis. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the 20th century, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially. Climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires and find that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of human-caused ignitions.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that this work will inspire future research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of the virus. Our results can help in the design of effective treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and the breakdown of the coral reef. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This study also highlights the importance of considering the metabolic interactions between the host and its symbionts in the interpretation of the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex ecosystem of commensal bacteria that is essential for the health of the host. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor in a Drosophila model of intestinal cancer leads to a loss of the intestinal barrier, which in turn leads to the loss of the microbiome. We also show that the loss of the microbiome leads to the loss of the tumor, highlighting the importance of the microbiome in the maintenance of the intestinal barrier. Our results identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the growth of intestinal tumors. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain the integrity of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in the development of cancer and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain homeostasis in the intestinal epithelium. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is variable, and many patients relapse. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to re-engrave Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may also be applicable to other cancers. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions that occurred exactly at the time of the transition to the Little Ice Age.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. Our analysis reveals that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for 158 million people, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the need to protect these resources. Our data can be used to inform the design of policies to protect biodiversity and improve the sustainability of inland fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential without triggering decomposition of water. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries.

The ability to regenerate is a defining characteristic of the nervous system, and the mechanisms that control this process are of great interest to both basic and applied science. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the nervous system. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the nervous system, and it also has implications for understanding the mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the nervous system.

The process of meiosis is critical for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are essential for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, the process of meiosis is complex, involving the formation of a double-stranded cross-over, or a gene conversion tract, at each locus to be inherited by a single daughter cell. We have developed a method to precisely locate the locations of these cross-overs and gene conversion tracts in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. Our results provide a detailed map of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant, and suggest that the process of meiosis in flowering plants is similar to that in yeast and mice.

The resting state network (RSN) is a fundamental concept in the study of the human brain. It is a small fraction of total neuronal activity, and its functional role is not yet fully understood. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is associated with cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the functional organization of the brain and its metabolic activity. They also provide a framework for the study of the functional role of the RSN in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate the stability and translation of mRNA. Here we describe a second 5′ cap structure in yeast, which is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We show that this cap is not a product of RNA editing, and is not found on rRNA or tRNA mRNAs. We also show that this cap is not a product of 5′ processing of pre-mRNA. We propose that this cap structure is a product of transcription and is important for the regulation of gene expression.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. The results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The results also suggest that epigenetic alterations at TXNIP, a gene involved in the pathogenesis of diabetes complications, may be a potential biomarker for the assessment of the metabolic memory phenomenon. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. (PsycINFO Database Record

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease that is associated with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds in fruit is a complex process that is influenced by many factors, including the species, variety, and developmental stage of the fruit. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of a group of volatile compounds in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce a wide range of nitrogenous volatile compounds. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant biochemistry and flavor chemistry. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is often used to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem services. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a critical finding for the future of the world’s ecosystems, and for the ability of ecosystems to provide the services that are essential for human well-being.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that the cell types are not completely segregated in space and activity. These data suggest that the organization of MEC cell types is more complex than previously thought. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types in the brain, which will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates that the flowering signal FT is a key component of the interplant flowering signal network. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of a flowering signal that is required for both host and parasite flowering. This study may help to understand the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also provides a unique example of a flowering signal that is required for both host and parasite flowering.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra, the classic site of degeneration in Parkinson’s disease, receive input from striatonigral fibers that originate in striosomes, a newly discovered region of the striatum. These striosome–striatonigral bouquet-like formations are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are often told that we “click” with people, but how do we know when we do? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We show that people feel more connected to the degree that their partner responds quickly to them, and that this signal is used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of social networks, the development of social bonds, and the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate and are therefore critical for the regulation of cardiac output. However, the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN function and may provide a molecular target for the development of novel therapeutics for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense has been controversial. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the defense response to insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, which are the main cell type involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a computational model of language that is based on a single mechanism: the ability to maintain information in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is not reliant on the maintenance of elevated firing rates, feedback, or plasticity. We show that this mechanism can support memory for information that is stored in the brain for milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to internalize into cells of mature plants, deliver siRNAs, and effectively silence a constitutively expressed gene in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves. We show that nanostructure internalization into plant cells and corresponding gene silencing efficiency depends on the nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. We further confirm that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology community and will help in the design of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery

Eutrophication of lakes and reservoirs is a growing concern in the United States and worldwide. In many cases, the cause of eutrophication is the discharge of nutrients from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that the nutrient loads and concentrations delivered to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, by its tributaries are highly variable, with the 6 largest tributaries accounting for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries delivered loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may play a greater role in driving coastal eutrophication than previously thought. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work highlights the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal fluctuation” phenomenon in physics, where the system is driven to a state that maximizes the rate of information transfer between the system and its environment. Our results suggest that the optimal fluctuation phenomenon may be a general feature of complex systems that are exposed to strong environmental forcing.

We show that the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain are not limited to the disruption of receptor function, but also include changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain. These changes can lead to the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are a hallmark of the disease. This work offers a mechanistic understanding of the effects of the antibodies, which may help in the development of new treatments.

The history of carbon (C) perturbations throughout Earth’s history has been a key focus of the scientific community. However, the history of C perturbations during abrupt warming events has been less well understood. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate a major C perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a glacial state. We show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C and to widespread seafloor anoxia. Modeling indicates that the event was linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and nutrient fluxes, which may have been driven by changes in ocean circulation and ice sheet extent. This work provides insights into the history of carbon perturbations during abrupt warming events and the potential for such perturbations to occur in the future. (Less)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of rigorous monitoring of certification impacts in the context of the climate and biodiversity crises.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex in vertebrates is a fundamental question in biology. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at that locus. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at multiple loci. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has a sex determination system with multiple interacting sex determination loci, and we show that this system produces a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide insight into the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. They also provide a model for the evolution of sexual polymorphism. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination systems in general.

The retina is a unique tissue in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A. One class of ROS is generated by the metabolism of the lipofuscin pigments, which are present in all cells of the body. The other class of ROS is generated by the metabolism of the photoprotective retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) pigment, A2E. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP) reduces the oxidation and degradation of A2E in the presence of light, which is important for maintaining photoreceptor cell viability. This finding is important because the Fe chelator DFP is used to treat Fe deficiency in humans. Thus, the Fe chelator DFP may be useful in the treatment of retinal diseases associated with the oxidation and degradation of A2E. This study also provides a rationale for the use of DFP in the treatment of retinal diseases associated with the oxidation and degradation of the lipofuscin pigments. (Read more)

Predator specialization is a fundamental aspect of ecology and evolution, but it is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators is not a dead end, and that they can evolve into generalists. We also show that the evolution of siphonophore nematocysts is linked to the evolution of prey type, and that the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations is linked to the evolution of prey type. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the hand is fragmentary, and the earliest hominins are represented by only a few isolated bones. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human-like tool use. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We have shown that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cell lines, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We have also shown that the one-carbon donor formate is a rescue for SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We have identified a glycine import defect in a subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is a particularly sensitive cancer cell-line model for SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and a targetable metabolic vulnerability of B-cell lymphoma. This work has the potential to improve the treatment of cancer patients. (Show more)

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can lead to a reduction in vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can lead to an increase in vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest animals that walked Earth. This has led to the compaction of the soil, which is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural land. We show that the weight of farm machinery has increased so much that the compaction of the soil has now become a global problem. We also show that the compaction of the soil has become so severe that it is now a threat to the ecological functioning of the soil.
